title: Aberdeen funds boss Martin Gilbert admits: I jumped before I was pushed
text:
Martin Gilbert already has the look of a man on the wind-down.

Slouching back in his chair in one of the many conference rooms in Standard Life Aberdeen’s City of London HQ, Gilbert’s ruddy face is peppered with stubble, he’s dropped his jacket and tie, and his well-worn white shirt has two buttons undone, baring a flash of his white chest hair.

It’s not quite the look we’ve come to expect from a man like Gilbert – the City grandee, the master schmoozer and Square Mile socialite.

But last week marked the end of an era for the 64-year-old Scot, who co-founded Aberdeen Asset Management 36 years ago. Standard Life Aberdeen – a group formed from the 2017 merger of Aberdeen and Standard Life, run by Gilbert’s friend, Keith Skeoch – announced that its vice-chairman would be standing down next September.

Winding down: But Martin Gilbert is set to become Revolut chairman

Until March this year, Gilbert, along with Skeoch, was co-chief executive of the group. He joked last week that his decision to step down and become vice-chair was motivated by a realisation that he had become the FTSE 100’s second-oldest chief executive. But today, Gilbert reveals that he decided to jump because he feared being pushed out by new chairman Sir Douglas Flint.

‘I wanted to take my destiny in my own hands,’ he says. ‘My decision to step down as CEO – and this is entirely my decision to do what I’m doing – was because I didn’t want to put Sir Douglas Flint into the position of having to tap me on the shoulder and say: “Come on, it’s time to go.” ’

Was an intervention from Flint on the cards? ‘Definitely.’ Why? ‘Because he needs succession. At some stage – I don’t know when he would have done it. But I never wanted to put him in that position… It’s better to take control of your own destiny and go when people are still sorry to see you go rather than cling on.’

Gilbert’s City career is far from over. He remains on the board of mining giant Glencore, and is set – pending regulatory approval – to become the chairman of challenger bank Revolut.

Gilbert reveals that he decided to jump because he feared being pushed out by new chairman Sir Douglas Flint (pictured)

No doubt Gilbert’s credentials in the start-up world will be boosted by his newly stubbled chin and surprising penchant for US rapper Eminem. But he may choose to remain quiet about his longstanding friendship with his old golfing companion, President Donald Trump. ‘He divides the nation,’ Gilbert acknowledges. ‘I met him after he was nominated. I went to see him in New York after he won, and I haven’t seen him since then.’

Unlike many of his high-profile peers, Gilbert has tried his best to stay out of politics in recent years. ‘I can’t remember,’ is his response when asked how he voted in 2016’s EU referendum.

But beneath Gilbert’s attempt to dodge unwanted questions lies a serious point. He believes businessmen should hold back from expressing their personal views on politics – because doing so is generally counter-productive and turns voters’ heads the other way.

Martin Gilbert, 64: Eminem-loving golfer Gilbert likes |American rapper Eminem Family: Wife, Fiona, a professor of radiology at the University of Cambridge, and three children in their 20s and 30s. Lives: Aberdeen, with houses in London and Zermatt in the Swiss Alps. Hobbies: Skiing, golf and fishing. Favourite music: ‘Eminem – every time I say this, it causes mayhem. I do like him, actually.’ Favourite Eminem songs: Stan and Lose Yourself. ‘I think he’s brilliant.’ Favourite film: Chariots Of Fire. Favourite books: Golf books by Colin Byrne. Breakfast: Crispy bacon and eggs.

‘It’s best not to,’ he says. ‘I’ll tell you why: I’m not sure that people really respect our opinions…I remember being asked to give an opinion on Brexit by [a leading Remain campaigner]. I said: “If I give an opinion on it, it will swing another 100 voters against what you’re trying to say.” Because there is a deep cynicism around what people like myself think.’

Clearly, not every financier felt the same way. It emerged shortly before the referendum, for instance, that US investment banks Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan had donated £500,000 each to the Remain campaign. ‘It amazes me,’ says Gilbert.

Away from politics, Gilbert – unsurprisingly – is able to recall vividly his decades in the City. He still appears haunted by the split capital scandal of the early noughties.

Aberdeen was the largest fund manager accused of mis-selling by encouraging investors to put their money into investment trusts which they were wrongly told were virtually risk-free. The company agreed to pay out £78million in compensation and Gilbert was accused by MPs of being a ‘sophisticated snake oil salesman’.

‘It still amazes me we made it through,’ says Gilbert, who was asked by his board to stay on to save the business and its reputation.

Martin Gilber likes skiing, golf and fishing

Gilbert not only survived, but built up Aberdeen Asset Management – which recorded a profit of just £87 in its first-ever financial year – into a FTSE 100 business with nearly 3,000 staff before its merger with Standard Life. Businessmen and financiers have probably been knighted for less – could there soon be a Sir Martin Gilbert?

Gilbert looks bashful, and points out there was a Sir Martin Gilbert, a noted historian and author who died in 2015. ‘And I knew him!’ says Gilbert, explaining that, in a twist of fate, a Washington hotel once inadvertently put him in Sir Martin’s usual luxury suite. ‘That was good,’ he says. ‘Sir Martin phoned me up and I had to buy him lunch.’

So could there be a second Sir Martin Gilbert? ‘No, no. I think Sir Douglas Flint must be the only financier knighted in about the last 20 years. It’s not going to happen in the financial services world now, is it?’

Gilbert doesn’t appear to be leaving Standard Life Aberdeen on much of a high. Investor outflows and disappointing profits have seen the group’s share price almost halve – to 271p this weekend – since it was formed in autumn 2017. The deal was dubbed an £11billion merger, but the group’s current market value is less than £6.5 billion.

Despite the group’s recent struggles – caused mainly, Gilbert says, by external challenges facing the sector, including the rise of ‘passive’ funds which typically invest in indices like the FTSE and charge lower fees to clients – he feels that now is the right time to go.

‘I’m always taken by the remark – I’m not sure who made it – that when things are going well you don’t want to go, and when things are not going so well, you can’t go.

‘So I took the view that this was the ideal time to go because we’re back on the way up.’

authors: William Turvill For The Mail On Sunday
